title: penarth school celebrates teacher heroes teacher appreciation week
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe school, which has recently reopened its doors following the national school closures, has been applauded by parents for its handling of the pandemic and the focus placed throughout lockdown on pupil safety and wellbeing.This month sees students, parents and friends of the school, in the local community and further afield, come together to pay tribute to Westbournersquos teaching heroes.These are teachers who routinely go above and beyond their normal teaching duties ndash including providing unprecedented levels of support to pupils during the pandemic, both academically and pastorally initiating new ways of thinking and learning during lockdown to help pupils thrive and participating in initiatives outside school to help those in need in the wider community.Heres some of their teacher heroes:Year  teacher, Jessica ArmstrongThe inspirational DofE leader helping women and children in need.She is currently spearheading the Duke of Edinburgh Award scheme at the school, and also leads a iety of extra-curricular student groups including Running Club and Maths Booster Club to help pupils transition back to Maths class following lockdown.On Saturday she led a Duke of Edinburgh expedition training weekend for Year ,  and Sixth Form, where pupils learnt vital survival skills such as understanding kit and equipment, map reading and route planning, cooking and first aid.She accompanied pupils on a six-hour orienteering session, covering km through Dyffryn and Wenvoe.In addition to her day job, she is also involved with the charity Cardf Womens Aid which helps women and children who have been victims of domestic abuse and gender-based violence in often le-threatening situations.She has worked with the charity on setting up an Information Hub for women looking for support and advice.     Deputy Manager of Little Westbourne Nursery, Hannah BennettThe nursery leader who helped raise pound,She has worked tirelessly over the past year to ensure the wellbeing and happiness of the children in her care.She worked to keep the nursery running efficiently and safely during lockdown, when many local nurseries had closed their doors, manning the nursery with one other colleague for the children of key workers in addition to rolling out a lively programme of daily online learning and motivational activities for children at home. During lockdown, she also led one-to-one Zoom sessions with children and their parents to ensure the highest levels of pastoral support.She went above and beyond her normal teaching duties when, in March , she helped organise a fundraising campaign in aid of the Downrsquos Syndrome Association, inspired by a child close to the heart of Little Westbourne Nursery, raising an incredible pound,.Stuart Ayres, Director of Online LearningThe innovative teacher helping students gain new skills during lockdownWestbourne is one of the first schools in Wales to use AItechnology to help pupils learn.It was also ahead of the curve in its appointment of a Director of Online Education before the UK went into lockdown, meaning that Westbourne could move seamlessly to a full online learning offering from Day  of the nationwide school closures.Director of Online Learning, Stuart Ayres, established an innovative tech partnership that enabled the school to deliver a ground-breaking online learning  backed by articial intelligence and the latest thinking in neuroscience.MORE NEWS:The  works by generating mini-lessons that students use to complement their studies. If a student requires guidance in a particular academic area, the  recognises this and recommends mini-lessons to improve understanding.It can even do this in a cross-curricular sense, for example suggesting English mini-lessonsa studentrsquos misunderstanding of a Maths problem is based on a comprehension error. It also recognises when a student needs to be challenged, recommending limitless supplementary material in the core areas of English, Maths and Science.Westbourne School is based on Hickman Road, Penarth. Picture: Westbourne School Stuart Ayres said: ldquoDuring lockdown, we continued to explore new ways of teaching, new resources and cutting-edge technologies to support pupils at every stage.ldquoUniquely, Westbourne offered a combination of heavily personalised learning alongside the latest in AI-assisted learning technology, which undoubtedly helped our pupils to thrive."There has been concern in the media about students losing skills and academic knowledge during lockdown - it was quite the opposite in our case."Students actually came back to school with more refined digital skills than before, thanks to the new technology.ldquoArticial intelligence has now become part of the make-up of the school, and we continue to use it to enhance learning now that we are back in the physical classroom."In doing so wersquove been able to elevate the student experience at Westbourne to a whole new - and very exciting ndash level.Principal of Westbourne School, Dr Gerard Grfiths, said: ldquoWe count ourselves very lucky at Westbourne to have such a talented and dedicated teaching team. Teachers here regularly go far beyond what is required of them to support, motivate and engage pupils at an extremely high level.ldquoItrsquos only fitting that we take this opportunity, during Teacher Appreciation Week, to discuss and celebrate all that our teachers do on a daily basis, both in and out of school."Even during the pandemic, when the odds have been stacked against us all, their love for the job and desire to see pupils succeed has been unwavering. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Council and today faced a Proceeds of Crime Hearing.There the judge decided he must repay a signicant sum gained from his illegal activity over the next three months.Shared Regulatory Services , who undertake trading standards work across the Local Authority areas of Bridgend, Cardf and the Vale, began investigating Mr Payter after receiving a complaint from the Assay Office, the body responsible for testing and hallmarking precious metals.The Assay Office had carried out a test purchase from gemgems, a company operated by Payter and Stefan Hodgson from Newport, that sold jewellery on eBay.It revealed that an item was not silver as described and did not contain the advertised gem stones.Further testing by SRS found that other items of jewellery were also misdescribed and that cosmetics being sold were unsafe and possibly infringed trademarks.After executing a warrant for the home of Payter, SRS officers seized jewellery, cosmetics and pound, in cash.The investigation showed that Payter and Hodgson had been trading for five years and at one point ran a website calledgemsgems.MORE NEWS:Check out these photos of the ambitious transformation at Whitmore High SchoolNew Pathway College announced at University of South WalesOutdoor show to come to Barrys MEMO Arts Centre later this month!They had been buying items such as necklaces, bracelets, bangles and earrings from a website in China without verying that they were as described.Counterfeit cufflinks and belts were also identied along with cosmetics that werenrsquot safe to be used.Payter, from St Davids Cresent in Penarth and Hodgson, of Park Drive Newport, both plead guilty to  offences in total two under Consumer Protection from Unfair Trading Regulations, six under the Hallmarking Act, two under Cosmetic Product Enforcement Regulations and two under the Trademarks Act.     In August  they were sentenced to a total of  months in prison, reduced to  months for early guilty pleas, suspended for  months. The pair also had to pay a victim surcharge of pound each.Cllr Eddie Williams, Vale of Glamorgan Council Cabinet Member for Legal, Regulatory and Planning Services, said: ldquoThis was a despicable operation that took money from members of the public for items that were not what they purported to be."Great work by Shared Regulatory Services has led to this prosecution, which ensures that no more people will fall victim to this company.ldquoI welcome the signicant sum Mr Payter has been told to repay, which reflects the amount of money he made from the operation.ldquoThis case should serve as a warning to others operating illegally within our community. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. are concerns the Indian iant could see cases jump back up.Data from Public Health Englandshows a rise in cases from  to , this week in the UK, with the agency saying cases were ldquorising in the community and it was assessing the impact and severity of the iant.One response being considered is bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the situation was being monitored carefully and the Government ldquowill not hesitate to take further actionnecessary.However, a small number of areas are seeing a rise in cases as the India iant spreads across the UK.The Prime Minister has said there is "increasing concern" about the iant and warned the emergence of further new iants "pose a potentially lethal danger".Where is the India iant dominant Surge testing has been under way in parts of Bolton since  May, after Public Health Englandconfirmed the town is one of the main locations of the India iant, which was reclassied as a lsquoiant of concernrsquo last week.Cases of the iant in England increased from  to  as of  May, according to PHE figures, with almost half of these related to travel or contact with a traveller.The majority of cases of the India Covid strain are concentrated in the north-west of England, predominantly in Bolton, and in London.The iant is also thought to be the reason behind half of coronavirus infections in Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen and South Northamptonshire, although these outbreaks are still small.Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has submitted a request to the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation that all over-s in Bolton, along with the rest of the Greater Manchester area, are able to receive a Covid- vaccination ldquoto mitigate the risks of spread in those communities where we are seeing more transmission.     There are also around  to  cases of the India iant in parts of Scotland, including Glasgow, with these cases again connected to travel.The India Covid iant, officially known as B.., was first detected in India in October.It has been designated a ldquoiant of concern by PHE as it is thought to be at least as transmissible as the iant detected in Kent last year, known as B, which is now dominant in the UK.PHE said there is currently no evidence to suggest that the new Indian iant is more serious than previous mutations, nor is there evidence which indicates that this version of the Indian iant is resistant to current vaccines.Health experts said they ldquohavenrsquot seen any hint of a current Covid iant that can fully evade the effectiveness of vaccines.On Wednesday , the European Medicines Agency said it was ldquopretty confident that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant, a view that has been echoed by some British scientists.However, Professor James Naismith from the University of Oxford said not enough is known to say for sure whether the iant could frustrate the UKrsquos vaccination programme.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoThe vaccines donrsquot  per cent prevent infection for people.ldquoWhat they do is, they almost  per cent prevent hospitalisation and serious illness.ldquoWe donrsquot know enough to know yet whether the Indian strain will behave dferently than that.ldquoSo even the regular virus can infect people who have been vaccinated and sometimes you do get reinfection.Could the iant delay lockdown ending The growing number of India Covid iant cases in the UK has sparked concerns that the lting of lockdown restrictions, which is set for  June in England, could now be delayed.Ministers have also not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.Foreign Office minister James Cleverly said that the government will make decisions based on the data, and measures will be eased ldquoat a pace and in a way which is safe.Symptoms to look forThe main symptoms of coronavirus to look for include:a high temperature ndash this means you feel hot to touch on your chest or back a new, continuous cough ndash this means coughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste ndash this means youve noticed you cannot smell or taste anything, or things smell or taste dferent to normalMost people with symptoms have at least one of these symptoms, although some do not experience any. title: garden created lost stately home grounds opening pandemic delay
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBridgewater, theRoyal Horticultural Societyrsquos fth public garden, has been created from the historic grounds at Worsley New Hall, Salford, Greater Manchester, with a focus on the local community.It had been due to openin July , but after lockdown forced the team to all-but halt work on the site, send volunteers home and delay the opening, the gardenrsquos doors are being opened to the public nearly  months later. vw,vw,px, px"Bridgewater is theRoyal Horticultural Societyrsquos fth public garden At the heart of the -acre site, which the RHS expects to attract as many as a million visitors a year,is the historic estatersquos -acre Victorian walled kitchen garden ndash one of the largest in the UK which is now full of tens of thousands of plants.It features a kitchen garden designed by RHS Cha Flower Show gold medallists Charlotte Harris and Hugo Bugg which references the local industrial heritage of underwater canals taking coal to the nearby Bridgewater Canal.The kitchen garden includes a section highlighting agroforestry and permaculture, even growing ndash in a first for an RHS garden ndash nettles to highlight their value for nettle soup, wildle and to make fertiliser. vw,vw,px, px"Staff prepare for the opening There is also a paradise garden designed by Tom Stuart-Smith, a wellbeing garden for local people complete with a grassy ldquocloud-gazing mound, and an orchard filled with regional apple ieties and historic pears rescued from the remains of the kitchen garden.Restored Victorian greenhouses are heated by a biomass boiler using wood taken from the site and hexagonal allotment plots have been provided for community groups working with vulnerable people and for schools.The lake and woodlands, which feature a Chinese streamside garden created in collaboration with the local Chinese business community, have been restored and a play area installed.      vw,vw,px, px"The Chinese Garden There are bee hives rescued from under the floorboards of the garden cottage, pigs, bat boxes and butterfly and bee-friendly planting.But deer which had lived on site could not be rounded up and moved due to lockdown, and a decision to cull the animals to protect the garden from damage prompted a local backlash.The delay to opening the garden has proved to have a silver lining: while it signicantly slowed work last summer, it has meant areas such as the orchard and Chinese streamside garden are much further along than they would have been.Curator Marcus Chilton-Jones said he was pleased overall with the extra time, ldquoalthough I didnrsquot think that at the time.He said RHS Bridgewater is dferent from the charityrsquos other gardens because of elements designed to deliver community benefits first and foremost. vw,vw,px, px"the site is spread over  acres ldquoItrsquos not something thatrsquos been done and tucked in the back corner because itrsquos not quite smart or well done enough, itrsquos front and centre, he said.ldquoBuilding in all of these aspects from the outset rather than building them on afterwards means itrsquos very much part of the DNA of the site.ldquoItrsquos not just for middle class people to come somewhere posh for tea and cakes.The site will welcome thousands of schoolchildren each year, and the garden team will be doing community outreach at the same time as maintaining the site and developing new elements including back-to-back gardens and trial beds to test plants in a northern climate.RHS director general Sue Biggs said: ldquoWe feel that the opening of RHS Garden Bridgewater, our fth garden, could not be more timely after the terrible time everyone has endured over the last year.RHS Garden Bridgewater opens  May # Book your visit to enjoy a wander round the late spring and early summer garden and watch it grow through the seasons to come: https:t.co jNvfWK pic kFRTFdWLlmdash RHS BridgewaterMay , ldquoWe have been looking forward to this day for more than six years, during which time so many people have come together and enabled us to create a stunning new garden that we hope the people of Salford, Greater Manchester, the North West and beyond are proud of.She thanked Salford City Council and landowner the Peel Group which have collaborated on the project, as well as the local community, staff and volunteers who have worked to get it ready.ldquoThis is just the beginning as our garden will give people pleasure for generations to come, but right now I could not be more proud of this incredible group of people, and the monumental achievement of bringing to le our shared vision to create what we believe will become one of the UKrsquos greatest gardens, right in the heart of Greater Manchester, she said.Tom Stannard, Salford City Councilrsquos chief executive, said: ldquoItrsquos fantastic that RHS Garden Bridgewater will soon be open to everyone, creating another world class attraction in Salford and contributing towards tourism and economic growth in Greater Manchester.He said the council played a pivotal role in making the garden a reality, had negotiated an agreement for local residents to visit for free every Tuesday, and would see afor the city of several pounds for every pound invested.Salford City mayor Paul Dennett added: ldquoRHS Garden Bridgewater will be a world-class visitor attraction, bringing a range of important social, environmental, economic benefits and opportunities on a huge scale to the City of Salford and along with other developments such as MediaCityUK, which continues to strengthen Salfordrsquos reputation nationally and internationally as a vibrant city to live, work, visit and story: Pope calls for rethink on towns   Council gives the go ahead to big plans for TandrageeNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleA simply breath-taking homeThis property at  Newforge Road, Magheralin is without doubt one of the most desirable homes to come onto the market for sale in recent times.By The NewsroomFriday, th May , : am  "       "  It has been lovingly modernised, while at all times retaining many of the original features that one would expect from a property of its time. From the moment you step inside, the abundance of natural light is clearly evident, and runs right through the property. The recent extension to the rear is home to a breath-taking kitchen open plan to dining. ]]This elegantly designed section has a glass wall in addtion to glazes sliding doors leading onto the garden, and a trio of roof lanterns. The kitchen is the heart of every home, and this one benefits from an array of stylish cabinets and coordinating island with quartz countertop, further complimented by NEFF integrated appliances and an AGA range cooker. It lends itself naturally as a very sociable space, with the living room housing the multi fuel stove open plan to the dining area. There is an additional dual aspect drawing room with attractive open fire. On the first floor there are four generously proportioned bedrooms, and a family bathroom which can only be described as stunning. The suite comprises of a free-standing bath, walk in shower encloser and His and Hers twin basins with vanity unit, dual flush WC and heated towel rail. There is an additional bathroom ideal for guests to this home. Outside, the gardens are packed full of mature shrubs and trees providing the perfect haven for entertaining with complete privacy. Mussenden Temple stands on the clf, from where there are views of counties Donegal Coast, Antrim and Londonderry. Staycation Northern Ireland: Seven Castles in NI that you can holiday in as Coronavirus restricts easeIf you’re planning a romantic getaway, make it a spectacular one.By The NewsroomThursday, th May , : pmUpdated Thursday, th May , : pm  "       "  Take your pick of these magical * castle retreats or stately manor homes, all in the most stunning locations in Northern Ireland. And all with plenty of interesting things to see and do around them. So, make dreams come true with a castle stay in Northern Ireland - evenit is only yours for a few days. . The Barbican GatelodgeStanding at the end of an old stone bridge across the Glenarm River, The Barbican Gatelodge is a charming building complete with gothic windows and a stone turret staircase. Early evening delivers the most spectacular views here. So get ready to head up to the roof garden to see the coastline in all its twilight glory. This self-catering accommodation is the perfect romantic hideaway and the ideal starting point for a road trip to discover the dramatic Causeway Coast, stopping off at the * Giant’s Causeway and * Carrick-a-Rede Rope Bridge en route. From the wonderful to the quirky, this is Northern Ireland’s past and it’s all yours to explore. There’s the perfect spot out there for your romantic getaway, so go get it.Photo: Google  "       "  Buy photo. Killyleagh Castle Towers, County DownBuilt in the th century by Norman knight, John de Courcy, Killyleagh Castle is the oldest inhabited castle in Ireland today, sitting close to the shores of Strangford Lough. The towers, where your self-catering property awaits, are by comparison mere newcomers. They didn’t put in an appearance till s and are actually built into the defensive walls of the castle. For the record, they go by the names of Ava and Blackwood.Photo: NITB  "       "  Buy photo. Ballygally Castle Hotel, County AntrimJust  miles from Belfast and close to Larne, the enchanting Ballygally Castle Hotelsits at the tip of the Causeway Coastal Route, with views all the way across the Irish Sea. The castle dates back to  and today is the only th century building in Northern Ireland still used as a residence. Character, charm, original beamed ceilings and restful contemporary décor add to the welcoming atmosphere. As does the reputedly friendly ghost. title: lidl plans new m concept store in omagh
story: Lidl has submitted plans to create a new, state-of-the-art concept store at its existing site on James Street, Omagh, as part of pound million investment which will add  additional new retail jobs this year. The modernisation plans will also support a further  jobs during construction and development. Located at the busy junction of Dromore Road and James Street, the store will occupy an entire space of , sq. metres – more than double the size of its existing store – which will include an expansive sales floor of , sq. metres. The planning application lodged with Fermanagh and Omagh District Council will see the demolition of a neighbouring pub and private dwelling to make way for the expansion on a site that will also incorporate a-space car park with two electric vehicle charging points and new, complementary landscaping. Construction plans encompass Lidl Northern Ireland’s bold ‘concept’ design which prioritises sustainability, spacious, wide aisles, long tills, restrooms, employee and baby-changing facilities which will dramatically enhance a high-quality shopping experience. The site will also include a large warehouse and improved employee welfare facilities. The application follows an extensive local consultation of the plans undertaken in September  which was positively received by local representatives and the wider community. Conor Boyle, regional director for Lidl Northern Ireland, said: “We are delighted to confirm plans for a replacement store in Omagh which will see the existing store at James Street in the town double in size to provide a dramatically-enhanced shopping experience and new jobs for the area. Centrally located in the west of the region, the Omagh store serves a burgeoning and thriving community base and is conveniently positioned next to the A which is a major primary route and commuter corridor. As a major investor in our communities and in our local economy, the Omagh store is an important location for us, and I am thrilled to reaffirm our commitment to the local area as part of this multimillion-pound investment. We hope to receive planning permission for the site in the coming weeks and we look forward to opening the brand new, state-of-the-art Lidl store later this year, bringing shoppers even more choice of
